\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}

\title{Literature review relevant for Numerical Representation of Orography}
\author{Hilary Weller}
\maketitle

\begin{itemize}

\item \bibentry{SZS15}
\item \bibentry{BKLL04}\ \\
hydrostatic reconstructions using discrete Archimides principle. No
reference state\\
No spurious vertical velocities for $\theta=$const. Otherwise max
w of \textasciitilde{}1e-2 for their test case

\item \bibentry{RCB05} \ \\
Boundary fitted coord systems lead to eqns with metric terms that
become singular over steep orography

Need vertical discretisation aligned with gravity for simple representation
of related physical processes (eg moist convection and sediment transport)

Mostly about SWEs, trajectories, RBFs. Also hydrostatic flow over
hill with cut cells vs terrain following. Not conclusive 

\item \bibentry{GGLR13}
\item \bibentry{GK00} \ \\
Hill test cases. Terrain following versus step orography. Gravity
waves 
\item \bibentry{Kle11} \ \\
STF coordinate - better than SLEVE. Resting atmosphere test case

\item \bibentry{KSF03} \ \\
Introduces flow with gravity waves over Schar hills

\item \bibentry{LBC+12} \ \\
Lit review on small-cell problem. Approach of this paper is to use
a small time-step

\item \bibentry{SBMB02} \ \\
Problems with step orography

\item \bibentry{Zan12}\ \\
The best horizontal pressure gradient

\item \bibentry{SLF+02} \ \\

\item \bibentry{Wym96} \ \\
Fig 2a shows what eta cordinates look like

\item \bibentry{MJN+88}
\item \bibentry{Rus07}
\item \bibentry{MCG+12}
\item \bibentry{Egg72} \ \\
This was cited by \cite{MJN+88}. Uses a blend between sigma and
eta. Cannot get hold of it. Inter-library loan?


\end{itemize}

\nobibliography{numerics}

\end{document}
